title: The Riddle of the Two Eagles
shortSummary: Ezekiel 17 presents a prophetic riddle involving two great eagles and a cedar tree, symbolizing the political alliances and betrayals of Judah during the Babylonian exile. The chapter reveals God's sovereign judgment on rebellion and His promise to restore a righteous ruler from the line of David. This passage highlights God's control over nations and His faithfulness to His covenant.
timeline: c. 593 BC - During the early Babylonian exile under King Nebuchadnezzar

keyCharacters.name: King of Babylon
keyCharacters.description: The powerful ruler who took Jerusalem's king captive and made a covenant with him, representing Babylon's dominance.

keyCharacters.name: King of Judah
keyCharacters.description: The rebellious king who broke his covenant with Babylon by seeking alliance with Egypt, symbolized by the tender twig.

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh of Egypt
keyCharacters.description: The foreign power from whom Judah sought military aid, opposing Babylon.

definitions.definition: A puzzling or enigmatic statement or question used here by God to convey a prophetic message through symbolism.
A solemn agreement or promise between two parties; here it refers to the political and divine agreements.

outline.heading: The Riddle of the Two Eagles and the Cedar
outline.description: God commands Ezekiel to present a riddle describing a great eagle taking a branch from a cedar and planting it, which grows into a vine that bends toward another eagle. This allegory symbolizes Judah’s political situation and questions the success of its alliances.

outline.heading: Explanation of the Riddle: Babylon’s Dominion and Judah’s Rebellion
outline.description: God explains the riddle, identifying the first eagle as Babylon, which took Judah’s king captive and made a covenant with him. Judah’s king’s rebellion by seeking help from Egypt is condemned, and God pronounces judgment on him for breaking the covenant.

outline.heading: God’s Promise of Restoration
outline.description: God declares He will take a tender twig from the highest branch of the cedar and plant it on a high mountain in Israel, symbolizing the future restoration of David’s line and the exaltation of God’s kingdom, demonstrating His sovereign power over all nations.

application: Trust in God's sovereign control over political powers and personal circumstances, knowing He can raise up and bring down leaders according to His will.
Remain faithful to God's covenant and commands, avoiding alliances or compromises that lead to rebellion against Him.
Recognize that God judges disobedience and covenant-breaking, encouraging believers to live in obedience and integrity.
Take comfort in God's promise of restoration and renewal, trusting that He will fulfill His purposes for His people.

keyVerses.text: Say thou, Thus saith the Lord GOD; Shall it prosper? shall he not pull up the roots thereof, and cut off the fruit thereof, that it wither? it shall wither in all the leaves of her spring, even without great power or many people to pluck it up by the roots thereof.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the inevitable judgment on rebellion and broken covenants, emphasizing God's sovereign power to cause failure.

keyVerses.text: As I live, saith the Lord GOD, surely in the place where the king dwelleth that made him king, whose oath he despised, and whose covenant he brake, even with him in the midst of Babylon he shall die.
keyVerses.significance: This verse pronounces the certainty of judgment against the disobedient king, underscoring the seriousness of covenant faithfulness.

keyVerses.text: Thus saith the Lord GOD; I will also take of the highest branch of the high cedar, and will set it; I will crop off from the top of his young twigs a tender one, and will plant it upon an high mountain and eminent:
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God's promise to restore a righteous ruler from David's line, symbolizing hope and divine restoration.

keyVerses.text: And all the trees of the field shall know that I the LORD have brought down the high tree, have exalted the low tree, have dried up the green tree, and have made the dry tree to flourish: I the LORD have spoken and have done it.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms God's absolute authority over nations and history, demonstrating His power to humble and exalt according to His purpose.
